item.title: Best Open-World Games With No Main Quest
item.description:
Summary

  • Kenshi sets players loose in a post-apocalyptic wasteland with no main quest, focusing on brutal survival.
  • DayZ thrives on emergent narratives as players navigate a zombie apocalypse with tension and paranoia.
  • Dwarf Fortress lacks mercy in its absurd complexity, offering a sandbox with no rules.

Not every open-world game needs a glowing exclamation mark to chase or a villain to hunt down. Some games throw the rulebook out the window and let players loose in a world with no central narrative to follow, just a sandbox of systems, survival, and moment-to-moment storytelling. These titles live and breathe without a main quest holding everything together, and somehow, that lack of direction makes them feel more alive, more personal, and, frankly, more dangerous.

Whether it's surviving brutal wastelands, building up a fortress in the middle of nowhere, or getting emotionally attached to a dwarf who drowns in a puddle he dug himself, these games thrive on unpredictability and freedom. Here are the best open-world games with no main quest, ranked not by story beats or boss battles, but by how compelling their chaos really is.

Kenshi

Don’t Expect A Hero’s Journey, Just Hope You Don’t Die In The First 10 Minutes

Kenshi
10.0 /10
Released
December 6, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
nr
Developer(s)
Lo-Fi Games
Platform(s)
PC
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Kenshi drops players into a post-apocalyptic wasteland where everything wants to kill them, and the most heroic thing they’ll probably do in the first few hours is crawl away from bandits with both legs broken. There’s no chosen one here, no ancient prophecy waiting to be fulfilled. What players get instead is a harsh, sprawling desert full of possibilities where survival is the only story that matters.

What makes Kenshi so unforgettable isn’t just its ruthless difficulty curve or its janky charm, but the fact that it’s essentially a life simulator set in a completely unstructured world. Players can become a farmer, a warlord, a drug smuggler, or just a guy who lost all his limbs and now lives in a swamp with robot legs. Towns rise and fall depending on who players ally with, and every single character has their own stats, hunger levels, injuries, and allegiances. There’s no handholding, no tutorial worth anything, and certainly no “main mission.” Just pure, unfiltered freedom wrapped in a survivalist fever dream.

DayZ

The Zombies Aren’t The Threat, It’s The Random Guy Waving At You

DayZ
12
8.5 /10
Released
December 13, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood, Strong Language, Violence
Developer(s)
Bohemia Interactive
Platform(s)
PC, Xbox One, PS4
OpenCritic Rating
Weak
Powered by

There’s technically an apocalypse happening in DayZ , but most players barely notice it over the sound of their own stomach growling and the paranoia of someone tracking them with a loaded rifle. This is a game where the only goal is to not die, and even that feels like a losing battle half the time. No story, no mission, not even a vague hint at salvation. Just a massive open world where every decision is a gamble and every other survivor is a potential executioner.

What makes DayZ so compelling is how much narrative emerges from silence. One player might spend hours scavenging for canned food and warm clothes, while another bleeds out on the floor of a church because they trusted the wrong guy. Entire storylines unfold in seconds: a gunshot in the distance, a betrayal during a trade, or a stranger silently saving someone from a horde. Its systems are barebones, but the psychological warfare between players more than makes up for it. DayZ thrives on tension, and it doesn’t need a main quest to be utterly unforgettable.

Dwarf Fortress

Losing Is Fun, And That’s Not A Joke

Dwarf Fortress
9.0 /10
Released
August 8, 2006

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
t
Platform(s)
Linux, macOS, Microsoft Windows
OpenCritic Rating
Mighty
Powered by

There’s no “start here, finish there” logic to Dwarf Fortress . Instead, there’s a procedurally generated world with centuries of simulated history, gods with grudges, ancient forgotten beasts, and a dozen dwarves who will absolutely get drunk and accidentally flood the entire base with magma. This game doesn’t just lack a main quest. It lacks mercy.

The beauty of Dwarf Fortress lies in its absurd complexity. Players aren’t just managing dwarves, they’re managing individual teeth, organs, personalities, grudges, and even favorite drinks. Fortress life spirals into chaos as dwarves fall in love, go mad, die from forgotten infections, or enter berserker rages after their pet duck gets eaten. And somehow, all of this is happening within a freeform world that doesn't ask players to do anything in particular. They can dig until they hit Hell, build a mountain library dedicated to cheese, or accidentally cause a civil war because they assigned the wrong noble. Dwarf Fortress is a sandbox with no rules and more stories per hour than most RPGs manage in a full campaign.

Elite Dangerous

Infinite Space, No GPS

Elite Dangerous
7.5 /10
Released
December 16, 2014

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Drug Reference, Fantasy Violence
Developer(s)
Frontier Developments
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 4
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Elite Dangerous is less about being a hero and more about figuring out how to make a living in a galaxy that doesn’t know or care that the player exists. With no campaign structure to hold it all together, players are dropped into a Milky Way replica of absurd scale, over 400 billion star systems, and told to do whatever they want. Smuggling, trading, bounty hunting, exploration, mining, piracy. It’s all there, just waiting for someone with the nerve and fuel to chase it.

The real hook is in the sheer loneliness of it all. Entire evenings can be spent warping between star systems, scanning planets, or plotting trade routes that might barely scrape a profit. And yet, it’s gripping. There’s no overarching narrative forcing a path, just small stories built from moments; flying too close to a sun, getting ambushed by pirates, or seeing a neutron star up close for the first time. With its player-driven economy, factions, and real-time galactic events, Elite Dangerous is what space really feels like: vast, indifferent, and full of quiet wonder.

Terraria

Who Needs Plot When You Have Explosives And A Grappling Hook

Terraria
7 /10
18
9.4 /10
Released
May 16, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Blood and Gore, Cartoon Violence, Mild Suggestive Themes, Use of Alcohol
Developer(s)
Re-Logic
Platform(s)
PC, Xbox 360, Xbox One, Xbox Series S, Xbox Series X, Vita, iOS, Android, macOS, Linux, 3DS, Stadia, PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Nintendo Switch
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Terraria may start off with players punching trees and avoiding slimes, but blink twice and suddenly they're fighting a giant eye at midnight while armed with a flamethrower and jet boots. There’s no campaign to follow or questline dragging them toward a climax. Just a world that responds to what players build, craft, and awaken. And that makes all the difference.

Its beauty lies in its layered progression. There are no explicit directions, but digging deeper, exploring corrupted biomes, and triggering world-altering bosses slowly transform a simple survival experience into a sprawling adventure. The game’s systems interact in chaotic ways; mine into the wrong cavern, and lava floods everything. Smash a shadow orb, and a boss spawns out of nowhere. Terraria encourages curiosity and risk-taking, and players who lean into its systems are rewarded with more tools, more madness, and more ways to destroy the landscape they once tried to protect.

7 Days To Die

Clock’s Ticking, And So Is The Landmine You Just Stepped On

7 Days to Die
16
9.3 /10
Released
December 13, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Strong Language, Violence
Developer(s)
The Fun Pimps
Platform(s)
Linux, macOS, PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One
OpenCritic Rating
Weak
Powered by

While most survival games ease players into their world, 7 Days to Die gives them a wrench, a deadline, and a vague hope they won't be eaten alive when the next Blood Moon hits. There’s no narrative, no tutorial worth trusting, and certainly no path forward. Just the knowledge that every seven in-game days, a zombie horde will arrive like it’s a cursed holiday tradition, and players better be ready.

It’s this countdown that makes the game feel so alive. Players aren’t just gathering supplies. They’re reinforcing walls, laying spikes, setting traps, and praying their base doesn’t collapse from structural instability (which absolutely happens). Crafting isn’t about cosmetics, it’s about survival. Building a forge isn’t exciting unless you realize it saved your life at 3 AM during a thunderstorm horde. The randomness of loot, the procedural generation of towns and terrain, and the fact that death comes swiftly if players stop paying attention all contribute to a game that thrives without a single objective. Every session becomes its own grim story of survival.

Minecraft

The Game With No End That Redefined Endless

6 Images
6 Images
Minecraft
190
9.0 /10
Released
November 18, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ Due To Fantasy Violence
Developer(s)
Mojang
Platform(s)
3DS, Android, iOS, Nintendo Switch, Nintendo Wii U, PC, PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4, PS Vita, Xbox One, Xbox 360
OpenCritic Rating
Mighty
Powered by

There’s a reason Minecraft has sold more copies than any other game in history. It’s not the lack of a main quest that defines it; it’s what that absence allows. From the moment players spawn, it’s just them, the landscape, and the decisions they make. Dig straight down and get burned alive in lava? Classic. Build a functioning 16-bit computer out of redstone? Sure. Spend 50 hours making a replica of Minas Tirith? Totally valid use of time.

Minecraft is deceptively simple. It lures players in with its blocky charm and then unveils an entire ecosystem of mechanics. Farming, mining, enchanting, breeding, building, modding, and redstone engineering; every mechanic is deep enough to become its own game. The community turned it into an art form, a coding tool, a storytelling platform, and a sandbox where imagination is the only quest that matters. Sure, there's an Ender Dragon somewhere out there, but in most worlds, nobody even bothers. The real story is always personal: the cabin built during a thunderstorm, the dog that never came back from the cave, or the creeper that ruined everything five seconds before saving.

item.title: Mortal Kombat 1: How to Solve Every Klue in Season 14 of Invasions Mode
item.description:
Season 14 of Invasions mode is a repeat of Season 6, the Season of the Reptile. There are 14 Klues in total, each of which can be solved by performing a specific Mortal Kombat 1 finisher or by spamming a certain attack.

Although the content may not have changed too much since it first ran back in June of 2024, the rewards that are on offer this time around are slightly different. As a result, both new and returning Mortal Kombat 1 players have a reason to complete all of the Season 14 Klues.

All Invasions Mode Season 14 Klue Solutions (MK1 Season of the Reptile Klues)

Klue

Node

Solution

Inputs

Rewards

RING A DING DING

Stay Back (Fire Temple)

Spam Sonya Blade's Energy Rings attack.

Press Forward + Kameo (R1 on PlayStation, RB on Xbox, or R on Switch).

  • Shadow Shredder (Epic Talisman)
  • 100 Seasonal Kredits

RECIHTR ALECS (Richter Scale)

Spear Some Change (Fire Temple)*

Spam Jax's Ground Pound attack.

Press Kameo (R1 on PlayStation, RB on Xbox, or R on Switch).

  • God Wave (Epic Talisman)
  • 100 Seasonal Kredits

SNOWBALL FIGHT

Doom & Gloom (Tarkatan Colony)

Perform any Brutality while playing as Sub-Zero.

N/A

  • Brute Force (Rare Relic)
  • Komodo (Liu Kang Palette)
  • 250 Seasonal Kredits

BTURAL HBDIRY (Brutal Hybrid)

Too Hot (Tarkatan Colony)

Perform any Brutality while playing as Mileena.

N/A

  • A Real Opener (Uncommon Relic)
  • 100 Seasonal Kredits

FROM THE SHADOWS

Say What?!?! (Sun Do Festival)

Perform Smoke's Hazed and Infused Fatality.

Press Back, Forward, Down, Front Punch (Square on PlayStation, X on Xbox, or Y on Switch) while standing at any distance.

  • Trash Talker (Rare Relic)
  • Steadfast Herptile (Raiden Palette)
  • 50 Seasonal Kredits

THROW $3000

No Peace (Rampart)

Spam Johnny Cage's Throwing Shade attack.

Press Forward, Down, Back, Back Punch (Triangle on PlayStation, Y on Xbox, or X on Switch).

  • Blood Klassic (Uncommon Konsumable)
  • 250 Seasonal Kredits

PET FOOD

Feeling Better (Rampart)

Perform Li Mei's Roman Candle Fatality.

Press Forward, Back, Forward, Front Kick (X on PlayStation, A on Xbox, or B on Switch) while standing at close range.

  • Performance Enhancer (Epic Relic)
  • 100 Seasonal Kredits

NAF NAF (Fan Fan)

Stage Fright (Rampart)*

Spam Kitana's Fan Toss attack.

Press Back, Forward, Front Punch (Square on PlayStation, X on Xbox, or Y on Switch).

  • Toxic Atmosphere (Epic Talisman)
  • Sorcerer of Light (Quan Chi Palette)
  • 250 Seasonal Kredits

ORGANS TRAIL

Mistakes Were Made (Living Forest)

Spam Havik's Seeking Neoplasm attack.

Press Back, Forward, Front Kick (X on PlayStation, A on Xbox, or B on Switch).

  • Python Kommander (General Shao Skin)
  • Flying Ace Kombat (Rare Relic)
  • 100 Seasonal Kredits

A WARRIOR'S DEATH

We Can All Be Friends (Living Forest)

Perform Goro's Prince of Pain Kameo Fatality.

Press Back, Forward, Down, Kameo (R1 on PlayStation, RB on Xbox, or R on Switch) while standing at medium range.

  • Herbal Tea (Rare Konsumable)
  • Steadfast Gavial (Tanya Palette)
  • 250 Seasonal Kredits

JADE REQUIREMENTS

Another Take (Living Forest)*

Spam Back Kick.

Press Back Kick (Circle on PlayStation, B on Xbox, or A on Switch).

  • Poison Drip (Epic Talisman)
  • 250 Seasonal Kredits

AND MORE BLADES

Bladed & Jaded (Flesh Pits)

Spam Baraka's Bleeding Blade attack.

Press Back, Forward, Front Punch (Square on PlayStation, X on Xbox, or Y on Switch).

  • Amulet of Lost Souls (Rare Konsumable)
  • 250 Seasonal Kredits

REFLECTION

Place Looks Familiar (Flesh Pits)

Finish the fight using Mileena's Fatal Blow.

Press L2 + R2 (PlayStation), LT + RT (Xbox), or ZL + ZR (Switch) while at low health.

  • One Punch (Epic Relic)
  • Ophidian Empress (Sindel Palette)
  • 250 Seasonal Kredits

DRAGON CHASER

Brought Friends (Flesh Pits)*

Hit all three enemies with both versions of Liu Kang's Dragon Tail attack (enhanced and regular), being sure to land the two attacks one after the other.

Press Back, Forward, Front Kick (X on PlayStation, A on Xbox, or B on Switch). For the enhanced version, press Back, Forward, Front Kick + Empower (R2 on PlayStation, RT on Xbox, or ZR on Switch).

  • Translucency Field (Legendary Konsumable)
  • Chaos Basilisk (Havik Palette)
  • 250 Seasonal Kredits

Players will only be able to access the Spear Some Change, Stage Fright, Another Take, and Brought Friends Nodes after beating Sinister Syzoth and obtaining the Reptilian Eye key item.

Mortal Kombat 1
8 /10
31
8.5 /10
Released
September 19, 2023

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
NetherRealm Studios
Publisher(s)
Warner Brothers Games
Platform(s)
PC, PS5, Switch, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
Powered by

item.title: Best First-Person Games With No Combat
item.description:
In a genre dominated by headshots and crosshairs, there’s something strangely brave about first-person games that skip combat altogether. These titles strip away the usual power fantasy and instead focus on immersion, storytelling, exploration, and puzzles. They make players slow down, observe, listen, and piece together their place in the world not with bullets, but with curiosity.

Whether it’s unraveling a mystery, walking through a memory, or solving ancient philosophical conundrums, these games prove that tension and satisfaction don’t always come from pulling a trigger.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter

Sometimes You Find More When You’re Lost

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter
7 /10
10.0 /10
Released
September 26, 2014

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
m
Developer(s)
The Astronauts
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, Switch, PC
Powered by

Red Creek Valley looks like something pulled from a dream, but it hides something far more haunting than its postcard-worthy forests suggest. In The Vanishing of Ethan Carter , players step into the worn shoes of paranormal detective Paul Prospero as he investigates the eerie disappearance of a boy with a vivid imagination and a family history better left buried. There's no combat or guiding arrow here, just the subtle art of observation, exploration, and a little ethereal deduction through ghostly memory reconstructions.

The visuals do a lot of the heavy lifting. This was one of the first titles to utilize photogrammetry technology for its environments, and it shows: rocks, trees, and rusted train cars appear to have been plucked straight from a forgotten American ghost town. While there’s no fighting to be had, the emotional gut punch of the ending might hit harder than any boss fight. Especially once players realize that some of Ethan’s darkest stories may not have been fiction after all.

Eastshade

Painting a World, One Step at a Time

3 Images
3 Images
Eastshade
9.3 /10
Released
February 13, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ // Mild Language, Use of Alcohol
Developer(s)
Eastshade Studios
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox One
Powered by

There are no swords, no enemies, no stamina bars, just a canvas, a brush, and the breathtaking open world of Eastshade . Set in a whimsical land where talking animals live peaceful lives, players take on the role of a traveling painter honoring their mother’s last wish to capture her favorite places on canvas. And that’s exactly what the gameplay revolves around: finding beauty, framing it just right, and turning it into art.

Rather than combat, Eastshade leans on discovery and gentle problem-solving. One quest might involve helping a bear catch the right lighting for his proposal, another may require solving a moral dilemma between two feuding villagers. It’s slow, sure, but that’s the point. The freedom to wander without danger and the joy of meaningful, small victories make it feel like a watercolor Skyrim with all the stress siphoned out.

The Talos Principle

Thinking in First-Person Isn’t Always Easy

The Talos Principle
8 /10
8.0 /10
Released
December 11, 2014

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Mild Language, Mild Sexual Themes, Mild Violence
Developer(s)
Croteam
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, iOS, Android
Powered by

Imagine Portal by way of 2001: A Space Odyssey, and you’ve got a sense of what The Talos Principle is reaching for. Players take control of a humanoid robot waking up in ancient ruins that shouldn't be here, guided by a booming voice claiming to be their god. The puzzles start simply: laser redirecting, pressure plates, timed doors, but spiral into devious complexity as new tools are introduced, like jammers, boxes, and time recordings.

But beneath the mechanics lies something far deeper. The game constantly questions the nature of consciousness, free will, and the purpose of life itself. QR codes left by other “test subjects” litter the world, hinting at past failures and existential dread. There’s no violence, no enemies, but there is a battle going on, for identity, autonomy, and maybe even a soul. Few puzzle games have ever been this philosophical or this quietly epic.

The Stanley Parable: Ultra Deluxe

You Can’t Trust the Narrator, But You Can Laugh With Him

5 Images
5 Images
The Stanley Parable: Ultra Deluxe
First-Person
Simulation
Mystery
Systems
Released
April 27, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen // Drug Reference, Mild Blood, Mild Language, Mild Suggestive Themes, Mild Violence
Developer(s)
Crows Crows Crows
Platform(s)
Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
Powered by

Stanley was employee 427. He pressed buttons. One day, he didn’t. That’s when everything fell apart, in the most brilliant way possible. The Stanley Parable: Ultra Deluxe takes the original cult classic and adds a fresh layer of surreal comedy and existential horror, all delivered through the silky voice of Kevan Brighting, who both guides and mocks Stanley through his increasingly absurd journey.

There’s no combat. Just choices, or at least the illusion of them. Whether it’s walking left when the narrator says right or unplugging a phone mid-monologue, everything feels like it matters and simultaneously doesn’t. The Ultra Deluxe version adds a whole new batch of endings, jokes, and meta-commentary on sequels and content updates. Players who enjoy breaking games, or being broken by them, will find this one endlessly rewarding and deeply funny.

Everybody's Gone to the Rapture

When the World Ends Quietly

Everybody's Gone to the Rapture
9 /10
10.0 /10
Released
August 11, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Violence, Blood, Suggestive Themes, Alcohol Reference, Strong Language
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 4
Powered by

Set in a sleepy English village frozen in the golden light of summer, Everybody’s Gone to the Rapture opens with an eerie question: where did everyone go? There’s no one to talk to, no one to fight. Only glowing trails of light that guide players through the remnants of a mass disappearance, and scattered recordings left behind by the town’s former residents.

The pace is intentionally slow, players literally can’t run for most of it, but it forces them to soak in the haunting stillness of Yaughton. Its real strength lies in its performances, with deeply human stories about love, fear, science, and faith unfolding one layer at a time. The game’s audio design, particularly Jessica Curry’s mournful score, does most of the emotional heavy lifting, making the silence feel heavier than any battlefield.

What Remains of Edith Finch

Memories Don’t Always Wait For You To Be Ready

What Remains of Edith Finch
9 /10
9.3 /10
Released
April 25, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Violence, Blood, Drug Reference, Language
Developer(s)
Giant Sparrow
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, PS5, Switch, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, iOS
Powered by

The Finch house doesn’t feel haunted at first glance. But as Edith returns to her childhood home and climbs through its sealed-off bedrooms, it becomes clear that the walls remember more than they should. What Remains of Edith Finch is a first-person anthology, each chapter presenting a different family member’s story and eventual death in a completely unique gameplay format.

There’s one where players control a fish that dreams of becoming a prince. Another where a comic book horror tale turns deadly. Each story is framed through Edith’s narration, but each death is felt more through its surreal presentation than any gore or violence. There’s no combat here, just quiet grief and a beautifully strange celebration of lives lost and remembered. It’s a short experience, but one that sticks in the bones long after it ends.

Gone Home

Sometimes Going Home Isn’t So Simple

Gone Home
10.0 /10
Released
August 15, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
m
Developer(s)
Fullbright
Platform(s)
PC, Xbox One, PS4, Switch, iOS, Linux
Powered by

It’s 1995. The rain is falling. And Kaitlin Greenbriar has just returned from a trip overseas to find her family home empty. What starts as a familiar "where is everyone?" mystery quickly becomes something more intimate in Gone Home . Players explore the Greenbriar residence, rifling through notes, cassette tapes, and hidden compartments to piece together what happened in their absence.

Despite its short length, every corner of the house tells a story, from forgotten pizza boxes to the posters of Riot Grrrl bands pinned to the walls. The central plot revolves around Kaitlin’s younger sister, Sam, and a personal journey, handled with a delicacy rarely seen in games. Gone Home feels like stepping into someone’s diary, and it helped define the “walking simulator” genre without needing any weapons, monsters, or chase sequences.

Firewatch

The Loneliest Watchtower in Wyoming

Firewatch
9 /10
10
8.4 /10
Released
February 9, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Suggestive Themes, Nudity, Drug and Alcohol Reference, Strong Language
Developer(s)
Campo Santo
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, Switch, Xbox One
Powered by

Firewatch opens with a gut-punch of a text-based prologue that sets the emotional stage long before players ever climb into the lookout tower. As Henry, players find themselves stationed in the middle of the Wyoming wilderness, watching for fires and speaking only via radio to their supervisor, Delilah. That conversation becomes the beating heart of the experience.

There’s no combat, no enemy, and yet a thick sense of paranoia settles in as strange things start happening in the woods. Someone’s watching. Files go missing. The line between imagination and reality starts to blur. But what sticks most is the bond between Henry and Delilah, full of banter, doubt, and awkward humanity. It’s a game that lets players wrestle with guilt, isolation, and the weird comfort of someone else’s voice crackling through the static.

The Witness

If a Puzzle Falls in a Forest…

The Witness
10 /10
8.6 /10
Released
January 26, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E For Everyone due to Alcohol Reference
Developer(s)
Thekla Inc.
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, PC, iOS
Powered by

Jonathan Blow’s The Witness is about drawing lines. Hundreds of them. Across panels, across the landscape, and, if you play long enough, maybe across the folds of your brain. The island may look serene: bright trees, clear skies, the gentle hum of wind, but it hides a tangled labyrinth of interlocking logic puzzles that get more devilish the deeper you go.

There’s no combat, no dialogue, not even background music. Just a player and the increasingly complex rules of its puzzles, which are often environmental in nature. Players start by tracing simple paths on flat screens, but soon they’re aligning tree branches, shadows, and architecture to solve riddles baked into the world itself. And if that sounds too abstract, the moment the screen fades and a hidden video starts playing, hinting at something philosophical lurking beneath all this mental gymnastics, it becomes clear that The Witness is asking questions far bigger than “Which way is up?”

item.title: Nintendo Switch Online Is Adding An M-Rated N64 Game
item.description:
Nintendo revealed that Forsaken 64 , a first-person shooter by Acclaim Entertainment, will launch on the Nintendo 64: Nintendo Classics Mature 17+ app on September 4. The arrival of Forsaken 64 on the N64 Mature 17+ app will mark the fifth game on the service, which requires an active Nintendo Switch Online membership along with the Expansion Pack upgrade.

Originally released in April 1998 for PC, Forsaken received a Nintendo 64 port in May 1998. A remaster of Forsaken was released on PC and Xbox One in July 2018 by NightDive Studios. NightDive, a subsidiary of Atari, currently owns the rights to Forsaken 64 and is credited with bringing the first-person shooter to the Nintendo Switch Online service. In Forsaken 64 , players control a bike-riding mercenary as they fight through hordes of mechanical terrors that have taken over a post-apocalyptic Earth. With split-screen multiplayer that supports up to four players, Forsaken 64 is considered one of the top FPS titles on the N64.

Forsaken 64 Is Coming to the Switch Online N64 App

Although the Nintendo 64's selection of M-rated games is not vast, Nintendo Switch Online subscribers will soon re-live a classic shooter. Forsaken 64 will launch on Thursday, September 4, at approximately 9:00 PM Eastern , on the Nintendo 64: Nintendo Classics Mature 17+ app. Players should bear in mind that the M-rated N64 app is a separate download from the mainline N64 app. An active Nintendo Switch Online + Expansion Pack subscription is required to play Forsaken 64 on Switch consoles. Nintendo revealed a short trailer for fans to peruse, which showed snippets of single-player and multiplayer gameplay. The arrival of Forsaken 64 will bring the total number of games on the N64 Mature 17+ app to five. The app's previous update was in October 2024, when Shadow Man and Turok 2: Seeds of Evil were released.

However, the reveal of Forsaken 64 may not come as a surprise to some keen-eyed Nintendo fans. Its arrival has seemingly corroborated a previous leak that claimed five games would arrive on the N64 app, including Forsaken 64 , Glover , and Super Smash Bros . The leak stated that a May 2025 trailer for the Nintendo Switch Online service featured blurred box art covers of five N64 games, which were reverse-engineered and posted by fans on social media.

Like other N64 titles on the Nintendo Classics app, Switch 2 users can use features like gameplay rewind and control remapping when playing Forsaken 64 . Though Nintendo has been sporadic in releasing updates to the Nintendo Classics app lineup, it remains to be seen what surprises the company has in store.

item.title: Best Sandbox Games For Feeling Like A God
item.description:
Summary

  • Sandbox games offer unparalleled freedom and potentially godlike powers to shape game worlds and influence their characters.
  • Specific games like WorldBox and Spore allow players to feel like deities as they create and control life.
  • Achieve godlike status in games like Minecraft and Terraria by reshaping the landscape and defeating powerful enemies.

Sandbox games allow for unparalleled levels of freedom, often with no particular goals in mind except for those set by players themselves. Some games in other genres even feature a sandbox mode to allow for unique experiences and creativity without constraints like resource gathering or pesky storylines getting in the way.

There are times when such freedom gives the impression of godlike powers, since the game world, characters within it, and various other aspects can all be influenced with the click of a button. These are some of the best sandbox games for feeling like a god, ranked based on a combination of their overall quality and how much they offer players a disposition of the divine.

8 Crusader Kings 3

Wield Great Authority Over The Medieval World

Crusader Kings 3
12
8.7 /10
Released
September 1, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teens: Drug Reference, Language, Mild Violence, Suggestive Themes
Developer(s)
Paradox Interactive
Platform(s)
PS5, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, PC
OpenCritic Rating
Mighty
Powered by

Medieval rulers generally had the unquestionable authority of God in many cases, with countless historical figures even claiming to be divine beings or having the powers of a deity. Crusader Kings 3 can potentially simulate this perfectly, especially for those who have experience in the game, allowing players to shape the geopolitical landscape of the world as they see fit, if they have the influence.

A great way of achieving godlike status is to invest in the dynasty tree, so that the family bloodline becomes stronger over the generations through powerful bonuses. Alternatively, it is possible to become the leader of a major world religion, thus altering the core tenets of the belief system at will and wielding unimaginable influence over all followers.

7 Fallout 4

Build Settlements & Mow Down Anyone In Your Way

Fallout 4

OpenCritic Rating
Mighty

Allowing players to build settlements that completely change the landscape and the world of Fallout 4 makes it much more of a sandbox game than other open-world RPGs that are labeled as such. Not only that, but leveling up and investing in some overpowered perks can make the Sole Survivor an unstoppable juggernaut, capable of taking down even the most formidable opponents with ease.

There are dozens of settlement locations awaiting development, and many NPCs who can be recruited to live there and perform tasks. Defending these built-up pockets from Raiders is important, but simple when possessing godlike combat strength. Other decisions can impact the social landscape of the Commonwealth, with player actions determining which factions gain significant influence.

6 Teardown

Skilled & Experienced Players Are Like Deities

Teardown
7 /10

OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Whether taking on the various heist missions or just causing anarchy, Teardown is a therapeutic game with unprecedented levels of voxel-based destruction. When handling highly destructive equipment like explosives and heavy machinery, it is quite easy to take damage, especially when standing inside or near a collapsing building.

Still, skilled players with more experience can wipe entire cities off the map, easily demolish buildings, and exterminate any hostiles who try to stop them, all while remaining unharmed and completing objectives. Of course, God mode can be enabled to grant invincibility and no restrictions on destruction, but even with this cheat disabled, godlike feelings can still be achieved after enough practice and using certain equipment correctly.

5 Terraria

Defeat Bosses For More Powerful Gear

OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

One of the best games with pixel graphics, Terraria can pose a serious challenge in the beginning, but it does not take too long for players to gradually feel more powerful and in control of the world. While exploring the large open world, there is an abundance of weapons and armor, as well as merchants who sometimes offer some fairly powerful goods.

The best way to unlock more effective gear is through defeating bosses, which may be a tall order early in the game, but offers little resistance later in the game if players craft or find the right equipment. By the time players face off against the Moon Lord, enemies that would have previously been fatal to encounter are decimated in one or two hits.

4 The Sims 3

Full Control Over An Entire Neighborhood

The Sims 3

As part of the popular life simulation series, The Sims 3 gives players control over the lives of their very own Sims. Most players will focus on one specific Sim or family, building their household, controlling their lives, and forging bonds with other Sims in the neighborhood, even those of a romantic persuasion.

Players may create and directly control everyone in the game world if they so desire, though they can only actively manage one household at a time. Not only can every aspect of a Sim’s life be decided by the player, but so too may their death. Some may become immortal and avoid meeting their maker through divine intervention, while other unfortunate victims may meet a grisly end at the player’s behest.

3 Minecraft

Transform The Land & Eliminate Anyone Who Gets In The Way

OpenCritic Rating

Minecraft is another game that can be tricky in the beginning, as starting with nothing leaves players in a vulnerable position until they can build a shelter, find food sources, and craft gear to fight hostile mobs. After a while, it’s relatively easy to become a formidable prospect for any challengers, easily surviving and thriving in the world, and reshaping it as desired.

Tinkering with enchantments, potions, and red stone is a practical way to make life easier, producing automated contraptions, strong weapons, and robust pieces of armor that grant various superhuman abilities. Though it may require a lot of effort, transforming the landscape is another way to feel in control of the world, from leveling a mountainous landscape to draining the sea, or simply building impressive structures.

2 Spore

Create Life & Watch As It Evolves

Spore
9.3 /10
Released
September 7, 2008

WHERE TO PLAY

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ due to Animated Blood, Comic Mischief, Fantasy Violence
Developer(s)
Maxis
Platform(s)
PC
Powered by

Starting with only a single-celled organism, Spore takes a species through distinct stages of evolution until they potentially reach a point where they can venture out to explore other solar systems. Controlling this lifeform throughout its stages of evolution is about as godlike as it gets, from the early days of just trying to survive to the latter stages of intergalactic colonization.

Entire planets can be terraformed to make the planet habitable for the player’s species, change its geography for aesthetic reasons, or simply to wipe out the life that already exists there. Other spacefaring empires can be impacted by player actions, whether by forming alliances with them or causing their untimely extinction.

1 WorldBox

Control The World

Worldbox - God Simulator
Simulation
Systems
Released
September 24, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
t
Developer(s)
Maxim Karpenko
Platform(s)
Android, iOS, PC
Powered by

Civilizations may rise and fall on a whim in WorldBox , a game where the entire world can be drastically transformed or destroyed with one click. Nothing is off limits, starting with a blank canvas or a premade map if desired, and creating a world for various creatures, humanoids, and other entities like Robot Santa and the dreaded Grey Goo.

Individuals in the world may be given certain attributes or traits, and they can be manipulated, depending on whether the player is benevolent or not. Clans and civilizations can be pitted against each other in a battle for supremacy, and natural disasters can be produced instantaneously to really spice things up, so the only real limit is the player’s imagination.
